RESOURCES

Our list of resources.

Extra Resources

Dyslexia Canada: Defines dyslexia, provides educational resources and community connections. And resources specifically for children such as videos, websites, and online/audio books.

How to Gamify Your Classroom: Steps for gamifying your classroom along with incorporating UDL principles. Defines gamification and why to use gamification in classrooms.

Managing Dyslexia with Gamification: Children with dyslexia are capable of playing video games despite their learning disability. What if gamified learning was used to tackle the many challenges facing efforts to provide affordable support to students with learning disabilities?

Top Teaching Strategies with Students with Dyslexia: Provides information on teaching strategies for students with dyslexia. Discussing how to create an inclusive classroom to promote a healthier, safer learning environment for all students.

Universal Design for Learning: Center for Applied Special Technology (CAST) provides resources and information on UDL guidelines Universal Design for Learning (UDL) is a framework to improve and optimize teaching and learning for all people based on scientific insights into how humans learn

Articles

Demir, Ü. (2020). An Examination of the Impact of Game-Based Geometric Shapes Education Software Usage on the Education of Students With Intellectual Disabilities. ECNU Review of Education. https://doi.org/10.1177/2096531120940721

Dymora, & Niemiec. (2019). Gamification as a Supportive Tool for School Children with Dyslexia. Informatics, 6(4), 48. https://doi.org/10.3390/informatics6040048

Gooch, D., Vasalou, A., Benton, L., & Khaled, R. (2016). Using Gamification to Motivate Students with Dyslexia. In Proceedings of the 2016 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (pp. 969–980). Association for Computing Machinery. http://oro.open.ac.uk/45173/1/gamification_CHI2016.pdf

Su, C. H., Cheng, C. H. (2015). A mobile gamification learning system for improving learning motivation and achievements. Journal of Computer Assisted Learning, 31(3), 268–286. https://doi.org/10.1111/jcal.12088

Videos

Constructivism in Education: defines the learning theory and how to implement the principles when teaching.

What is Dyslexia?: Kelli Sandman-Hurley presents how the experience of dyslexia isn't always the same. This difficulty in processing language exists along a spectrum -- one that doesn't necessarily fit with labels like "normal" and "defective." urges us to think again about dyslexic brain function and to celebrate the neurodiversity of the human brain.

Power of Gamification in Education: Scott Hebert discusses how modern education system is experiencing an engagement crisis and how we can solve it through a new approach in teaching. #GameMyClass

Learning Via Your Style: Education expert DJ Cunningham details his struggles with dyslexia growing up and demonstrates the value of viewing learning disabilities as learning differences.

UDL at a Glance: offers an overview of the guidelines for incorporating Universal Design for Learning (UDL) into the classroom.

Universal Design for Learning: UDL: outlines why teachers should use UDL and the benefits. Exploring the principles and how to implement them in a classroom setting.
